intro: Pimpinella saxifraga var. hircina, commonly known as the sheep's parsley, is a flowering plant native to southern Europe and parts of western Asia. It is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves and small yellow flowers that bloom in late spring. The plant typically grows in rocky or limestone soils, often in open woodland or along streambanks. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes other aromatic herbs such as carrots and dill. Its habitat preferences and ornamental qualities make it a notable species in botanical gardens and natural habitats.
